for most sap systems is to use the general purpose uh ebs volumes but then the
the few bullet points down bottom you would still follow the standard best practices for ebs volumes

take that into consideration
so for support and monitoring of uh sap systems on aws um not sure if all customers are aware
of this requirement but for a production system there are requirements in note
165 6250 which outline what is needed by sap support in order
for them to support an sap system running on aws so the the two primary requirements are
enabling cloudwatch detailed monitoring which versus basic
which provides metrics in a five minute interval the detailed monitoring provides them in a one minute interval
and then we have developed the aws data provider which
surfaces performance metrics from the aws layer up to the sap layer
so sap can can from the sap layer get a picture of
what's happening below so for any production systems running on
aws these requirements need to be met and set up and configured
so i think this might be one of my one or two last slides um so disaster recovery um again this is a
topic that we could probably do a whole 30 minute presentation on but just to touch the surface there's
two primary scenarios so we have customers that are looking to use aws as the dr site for their on-premises
sap environment and we have i think i have a case study in the end of a customer doing just that
and then we have customers needing to provide disaster recovery for their production sap environments
that are already running on aws but they both are going to have the same requirements which is first
determining what are the the recovery time objective and recovery point objectives
and then the next being you know what's the required geographical separation of the primary
and dr site and that's that's more of a point for the case where you're needing to provide
dr for a production environment that's running on aws so then the the two primary patterns or
architectures depending on the requirements would be either the the lower cost but higher rpo rto which is
just the backup and recovery so you're you're storing backups of your production system
um if we're if it's the requirement is production on premises and dr on aws
you're just storing the backups on aws and at the time of a disaster you're
rebuilding your production environment from those backups but since it's using a backup restore
it's you know you're going to have longer time to recover your environment you're also going to have
more data loss the other scenario would be the having a replicated standby system so
having an online standby system of either you know if you
had an erpc or mbw have each of them with the database being replicated
uh which then would enable lower rpo and rto and then just in that scenario we have a
um a general aws dr document not specific to sap but that then covers about four
different uh patterns just for that model uh one being what's called the pilot light
scenario so you could have the smallest possible database server running just to keep in sync
maybe if your production had a an 8 by 64 database server your standby system
could be a 4 by 32 and then at the time of a dr you can increase that
and also maybe your production environment has three or four app servers your dr environment you don't have any
app servers online but at the time of a disaster you could bring app servers online so you're only paying for that small
pilot light which is the smallest possible database server um or you could have a you know a full
online ready and running uh dr environment
and then the the other question with if if you're running production on aws
is to use a second availability zone in the same region as the dr site
or if a larger geographical separation is required using a different region of aws or using
a combination of both so because of what we provide with our availability zones and the
the high speed low latency network being able to have a a synchronous uh standby system in a
second availability zone and maybe having a either using a backup recovery scenario
in a separate region or an asynchronous standby system in
in a separate region and another topic again we can really
just touch the surface in this is high availability of sap
systems running on on aws so on a traditional infrastructure
the pattern or architecture would be using a failover cluster with two nodes and shared storage
and this would normally be done in a single data center to protect against failure of individual components like
servers or storage so on aws we currently don't have
the ability for shared storage so the the pattern on aws would be uh replicated database servers um
sap enqueue replication i have a link down bottom which we have a guide which covers this
but then um being able to gain the added benefit of spreading
those across availability zones so now you're not only protected against a failure of a component in a data
center you can be protected against a failure of an entire data center by moving your replicated database to
another availability zone and again because of the high speed low latency network being able to actually
have a synchronous standby system
